facts: Stars are huge balls of hot gas, mostly hydrogen and helium, that shine because of nuclear fusion in their cores.
The closest star to Earth is the Sun, and its light takes about 8 minutes to reach us.
When you look at stars in the night sky, you are seeing them as they were in the past because their light takes time to travel.
A starâ€™s color can tell you its temperature: blue-white stars are hottest, and red stars are cooler.
Most stars are part of systems with two or more stars orbiting each other, called binary or multiple-star systems.
Stars are born in giant clouds of gas and dust called nebulae, where gravity pulls material together to form a new star.
Massive stars can end their lives in powerful explosions called supernovae, which spread elements needed to make planets and living things.
